title: List of plants used in herbalism - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: List of plants used in herbalism This article may present This article needs more |This article is part of |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) This is an alphabetical list of plants used in [herbalism](/wiki/Herbalism). [Phytochemicals](/wiki/Phytochemical) possibly involved in biological functions are the basis of herbalism, and may be grouped as: [primary metabolites](/wiki/Primary_metabolite), such as [carbohydrates](/wiki/Carbohydrate)and [fats](/wiki/Fat)found in all plants [secondary metabolites](/wiki/Secondary_metabolite)serving a more specific function. [[1]](#cite_note-meskin-2002-p123-1) - For example, some [secondary metabolites](/wiki/Secondary_metabolite) are [toxins](/wiki/Toxin) used to [deter predation](/wiki/Plant_defense_against_herbivory), and others are [pheromones](/wiki/Pheromone) used to attract insects for [pollination](/wiki/Pollination). Secondary metabolites and pigments may have therapeutic actions in humans, and can be refined to produce drugs; examples are [quinine](/wiki/Quinine) from the [cinchona](/wiki/Cinchona), [morphine](/wiki/Morphine) and the [digoxin](/wiki/Digoxin) from the [foxglove](/wiki/Digitalis). [[1]](#cite_note-meskin-2002-p123-1) In Europe, [apothecaries](/wiki/Apothecary) stocked herbal ingredients as [traditional medicines](/wiki/Traditional_medicine). In the [Latin names for plants](/wiki/Binomial_nomenclature) created by [Linnaeus](/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus), the word [officinalis](/wiki/Officinalis) indicates that a plant was used in this way. For example, the [marsh mallow](/wiki/Althaea_officinalis) has the classification Althaea officinalis, as it was traditionally used as an [emollient](/wiki/Emollient) to soothe [ulcers](/wiki/Ulcer). [[2]](#cite_note-haubrich-2) [Pharmacognosy](/wiki/Pharmacognosy) is the study of plant sources of phytochemicals. Some modern [prescription drugs](/wiki/Prescription_drug) are based on plant [extracts](/wiki/Extract) rather than whole plants. The phytochemicals may be synthesized, compounded or otherwise transformed to make [pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Pharmaceutical). Examples of such derivatives include [aspirin](/wiki/Aspirin), which is chemically related to the [salicylic acid](/wiki/Salicylic_acid) found in [white willow](/wiki/White_willow). The opium poppy is a major industrial source of opiates, including [morphine](/wiki/Morphine). Few traditional remedies, however, have translated into modern drugs, although there is continuing research into the efficacy and possible adaptation of traditional herbal treatments. A[ used on [snakebites](/wiki/Snakebite). The smoke from burning leaves is used to revive unconscious people. [[54]](#cite_note-54)Digoxin is used least 400 years by [Native Americans](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas)to treat [infections](/wiki/Infection)and wounds, and as a general "cure-all" ( [panacea](/wiki/Panacea)). It is currently used "Indian tea". It contains the [[62]](#cite_note-62)The US Forest Service profile [[63]](#cite_note-63)for Eriodictyon crassifolium provides information on species distribution; taxonomic relationships; ecological and evolutionary considerations for restoration; growth form and distinguishing traits; habitat characteristics; projected future suitable habitat; growth, reproduction and dispersal; biological interactions; ecological genetics; seed characteristics, germination requirements and processing; and plant uses including agriculture, restoration, and traditional products, plus an extensive bibliography. It is part of Riverside-Corona Resource Conservation District's resource materials collection on native plant recommendations for southern California ecoregions. However, Howard (1987) warns that fumitory is [poisonous](/wiki/Poison)and should only be used under the direction of a medical herbalist. In the traditional Austrian medicine Plantago lanceolata leaves have been used internally (as syrup or tea) or externally (fresh leaves) for treatment of disorders of the respiratory tract, skin, insect bites, and infections.
